DataElement.preferredName: Tumor/Lesion Identification Supplemental Qualifiers Dataset WHO Classification of Tumors Acute Myeloid Leukemia Category
DataElement.preferredDefinition: World Health Organization disease classification on acute myeloid leukemia.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Tumor/Lesion Identification Supplemental Qualifiers Dataset WHO Classification of Tumors Acute Myeloid Leukemia
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: _A dataset containing supplemental information, specifically non-standard variables, to parent records in the tumor/lesion identification domain:A classification of benign and malignant tumors by World Health Organization (WHO) experts based primarily on histologic findings._A clonal expansion of myeloid blasts in the bone marrow, blood or other tissues. The classification of acute myeloid leukemias (AMLs) encompasses four major categories: 1) AML with recurrent genetic abnormalities; 2) AML with multilineage dysplasia; 3) Therapy-related AML; 4) AML not otherwise specified. The required bone marrow or peripheral blood blast percentage for the diagnosis of AML is 20% (WHO classification).

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A dataset containing supplemental information, specifically non-standard variables, to parent records in the tumor/lesion identification domain.

Concepts.definition: A dataset containing supplemental information, specifically non-standard variables, to parent records in the tumor/lesion identification domain.

Property.preferredName: WHO Classification of Tumors Acute Myeloid Leukemia
Property.preferredDefinition: A classification of benign and malignant tumors by World Health Organization (WHO) experts based primarily on histologic findings._A clonal expansion of myeloid blasts in the bone marrow, blood or other tissues. The classification of acute myeloid leukemias (AMLs) encompasses four major categories: 1) AML with recurrent genetic abnormalities; 2) AML with multilineage dysplasia; 3) Therapy-related AML; 4) AML not otherwise specified. The required bone marrow or peripheral blood blast percentage for the diagnosis of AML is 20% (WHO classification).

Concepts.definition: A classification of benign and malignant tumors by World Health Organization (WHO) experts based primarily on histologic findings.

A clonal expansion of myeloid blasts in the bone marrow, blood or other tissues. The classification of acute myeloid leukemias (AMLs) encompasses four major categories: 1) AML with recurrent genetic abnormalities; 2) AML with multilineage dysplasia; 3) Therapy-related AML; 4) AML not otherwise specified. The required bone marrow or peripheral blood blast percentage for the diagnosis of AML is 20% (WHO classification).

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: An organizational header for concepts representing mostly abstract entities.

DataElementConcept.origin: COG CRF:Children's Oncology Group Case Report Form

ValueDomain.preferredName: World Health Organization Acute Myeloid Leukemia Category
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A United Nations agency established to coordinate international health activities and to help governments improve health services._A clonal expansion of myeloid blasts in the bone marrow, blood or other tissues.  The classification of acute myeloid leukemias (AMLs) encompasses four major categories: 1) AML with recurrent genetic abnormalities 2) AML with multilineage dysplasia 3) Therapy-related AML 4) AML not otherwise categorized.  The required bone marrow or peripheral blood blast percentage for the diagnosis of AML has been recently reduced from 30% (French-American-British [FAB] classification) to 20% (WHO classification).  (WHO, 2001) -- 2003_Category; used informally to mean a class of things.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with Myelodysplasia-Related Changes

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with Myelodysplasia-Related Changes
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia with at least 20% blasts in the bone marrow or blood, and either a previous history of myelodysplastic syndrome, multilineage dysplasia or myelodysplastic syndrome-related cytogenetic abnormalities. There is no history of prior cytotoxic therapy for an unrelated disorder, and there is absence of the cytogenetic abnormalities that are present in acute myeloid leukemia with recurrent genetic abnormalities.

Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia with at least 20% blasts in the bone marrow or blood, and either a previous history of myelodysplastic syndrome, multilineage dysplasia or myelodysplastic syndrome-related cytogenetic abnormalities.  There is no history of prior cytotoxic therapy for an unrelated disorder, and there is absence of the molecular abnormalities that are present in acute myeloid leukemia with recurrent genetic abnormalities.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Acute Panmyelosis with Myelofibrosis

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Panmyelosis with Myelofibrosis
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia characterized by bone marrow fibrosis without preexisting primary myelofibrosis.

Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia characterized by bone marrow fibrosis without preexisting primary myelofibrosis.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Acute Basophilic Leukemia

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Basophilic Leukemia
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A rare acute myeloid leukemia in which the immature cells differentiate towards basophils.

Concepts.definition: A rare acute myeloid leukemia in which the immature cells differentiate towards basophils.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Acute Megakaryoblastic Leukemia

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Megakaryoblastic Leukemia
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia in which at least 50% of the blasts are of megakaryocytic lineage. (WHO, 2001)

Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia in which at least 50% of the blasts are of megakaryocytic lineage. (WHO, 2001)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Erythroleukemia

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Erythroleukemia
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Acute erythroid leukemia characterised by the presence of at least 50% erythroid precursors and at least 20% myeloblasts in the bone marrow. -- 2003

Concepts.definition: Acute erythroid leukemia characterised by the presence of at least 50% erythroid precursors and at least 20% myeloblasts in the bone marrow.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Acute Erythroid Leukemia

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Erythroid Leukemia
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia characterized by a predominant immature erythroid population.  There are two subtypes recognized: erythroleukemia and pure erythroid leukemia. (WHO, 2001)

Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia characterized by a predominant immature erythroid population.  There are two subtypes recognized: erythroleukemia and pure erythroid leukemia. (WHO, 2001)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Acute Monoblastic Leukemia and Acute Monocytic Leukemia

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Monoblastic Leukemia and Acute Monocytic Leukemia
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Acute myeloid leukemia in which 80% or more of the leukemic cells are of monocytic lineage.  Bleeding disorders are common presenting features.  It usually follows an aggressive clinical course.  (WHO, 2001) -- 2003

Concepts.definition: Acute myeloid leukemia in which 80% or more of the leukemic cells are of monocytic lineage, including monoblasts, promonocytes, and monocytes. Bleeding disorders are common presenting features.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Acute Myelomonocytic Leukemia

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Myelomonocytic Leukemia
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute leukemia characterized by the proliferation of both neutrophil and monocyte precursors.  (WHO, 2001)

Concepts.definition: An acute leukemia characterized by the proliferation of both neutrophil and monocyte precursors.  (WHO, 2001)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with Maturation

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with Maturation
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia (AML) characterized by blasts with evidence of maturation to more mature neutrophils. (WHO, 2001)

Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia (AML) characterized by blasts with evidence of maturation to more mature neutrophils. (WHO, 2001)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Acute Myeloid Leukemia without Maturation

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia without Maturation
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia (AML) characterized by blasts without evidence of maturation to more mature neutrophils. (WHO, 2001)

Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia (AML) characterized by blasts without evidence of maturation to more mature neutrophils. (WHO, 2001)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Acute Myeloid Leukemia, Minimally Differentiated

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia, Minimally Differentiated
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia (AML) in which the blasts do not show evidence of myeloid differentiation by morphology and conventional cytochemistry.  The myeloid origin of the blasts is demonstrated by immunohistochemistry and/or electron microscopic studies.  The patients present with anemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia.  The prognosis is usually poor.  (WHO, 2001) -- 2003

Concepts.longName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with Minimal Differentiation
Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia (AML) in which the blasts do not show evidence of myeloid differentiation by morphology and conventional cytochemistry. (WHO, 2001)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with Mutated CEBPA

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with Mutated CEBPA
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia with mutation of the CEBPA gene. It is usually associated with normal karyotype and most cases meet the criteria for acute myeloid leukemia with or without maturation. Cases with normal karyotype have a favorable prognosis.

Concepts.longName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with CEBPA Mutation
Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia with non-germline mutations of the CEBPA gene.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with Mutated NPM1

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with Mutated NPM1
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia with mutation of the nucleophosmin gene. It is usually associated with normal karyotype and frequently has myelomonocytic or monocytic features. It usually responds to induction therapy.

Concepts.longName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with NPM1 Mutation
Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia with mutation of the nucleophosmin gene. It is usually associated with normal karyotype and frequently has myelomonocytic or monocytic features. It usually responds to induction therapy.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Acute Myeloid Leukemia (Megakaryoblastic) with t(1;22)(p13;q13); RBM15-MKL1

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia (Megakaryoblastic) with t(1;22)(p13;q13); RBM15-MKL1
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia associated with t(1;22)(p13;q13) resulting in the expression of RBM15-MKL1 fusion protein. It affects infants and children and usually shows megakaryocytic maturation.

Concepts.longName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia (Megakaryoblastic) with t(1;22)(p13.3;q13.1); RBM15-MKL1
Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia associated with t(1;22)(p13.3;q13.1) resulting in the expression of RBM15-MKL1 fusion protein. It affects infants and children and usually shows megakaryocytic maturation.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with inv(3)(q21.3;q26.2) or t(3;3)(q21.3;q26.2); GATA2, MECOM

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with inv(3)(q21.3;q26.2) or t(3;3)(q21.3;q26.2); GATA2, MECOM
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia associated with inv(3)(q21.3q26.2) or t(3;3)(q21.3;q26.2) resulting in the reposition of a distal GATA2 enhancer to activate MECOM expression. It may present de novo or follow a myelodysplastic syndrome. The clinical course is aggressive.

Concepts.longName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with inv(3)(q21.3;q26.2) or t(3;3)(q21.3;q26.2); GATA2, MECOM
Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia associated with inv(3)(q21.3q26.2) or t(3;3)(q21.3;q26.2) resulting in the reposition of a distal GATA2 enhancer to activate MECOM expression. It may present de novo or follow a myelodysplastic syndrome. The clinical course is aggressive.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Updated definition and VM Long Name_ghd_11.16.16

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with t(6;9)(p23;q34.1); DEK-NUP214

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with t(6;9)(p23;q34.1); DEK-NUP214
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia associated with t(6;9)((p23;q34.1) resulting in DEK-NUP214(CAN) fusion protein expression. It is often associated with multilineage dysplasia and basophilia. It affects both children and adults and it usually has an unfavorable clinical outcome.

Concepts.longName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with t(6;9)(p22.3;q34.1); DEK-NUP214
Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia associated with t(6;9)(p22.3;q34.1) resulting in DEK-NUP214(CAN) fusion protein expression. It is often associated with multilineage dysplasia and basophilia. It affects both children and adults and it usually has an unfavorable clinical outcome.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Updated definition and VM Long Name_ghd_11.16.16

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with t(9;11)(p22;q23); MLLT3-MLL

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with t(9;11)(p22;q23); MLLT3-MLL
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia associated with t(9;11)(p22;q23) and MLLT3 (AF9)-MLL fusion protein expression.  Morphologically it usually has monocytic features.  It may present at any age but it is more commonly seen in children.  Patients may present with disseminated intravascular coagulation.

Concepts.longName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with t(9;11)(p21.3;q23.3); MLLT3-KMT2A
Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia associated with t(9;11)(p21.3;q23.3) and MLLT3-KMT2A fusion protein expression. Morphologically it usually has monocytic features. It may present at any age but it is more commonly seen in children. Patients may present with disseminated intravascular coagulation.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with inv(16)(p13.1q22); CBFB-MYH11

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with inv(16)(p13.1q22); CBFB-MYH11
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Acute myeloid leukemia characterized by the presence of abnormal bone marrow eosinophils and the characteristic cytogenetic abnormality inv(16)(p13.1q22) which results in the expression of the fusion protein CBFB-MYH11.

Concepts.longName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with inv(16)(p13.1q22); CBFB-MYH11
Concepts.definition: Acute myeloid leukemia characterized by the presence of abnormal bone marrow eosinophils and the characteristic cytogenetic abnormality inv(16)(p13.1q22) which results in the expression of the fusion protein CBFB-MYH11.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: AML1-ETO Fusion Protein Expression

ValueMeaning.preferredName: AML1-ETO Fusion Protein Expression
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A fusion gene (~4.3 kb) that results from a chromosomal translocation t(8;21)(q22;q22) which fuses the first 5 exons of the RUNX1 gene to exon 2 of the RUNX1T1 gene. This rearrangement is associated with acute myeloid leukemia.::1: A fusion protein (752 aa, ~83 kDa) encoded by the RUNX1/RUNX1T1 fusion gene. This protein is comprised of the N-terminal runt domain of the runt-related transcription factor 1 protein fused to the 577 C-terminal residues of protein CBFA2T1.

Concepts.definition: A fusion gene (~4.3 kb) that results from a chromosomal translocation t(8;21)(q22;q22) which fuses the first 5 exons of the RUNX1 gene to exon 2 of the RUNX1T1 gene. This rearrangement is associated with acute myeloid leukemia.

A fusion protein (752 aa, ~83 kDa) encoded by the RUNX1/RUNX1T1 fusion gene. This protein is comprised of the N-terminal runt domain of the runt-related transcription factor 1 protein fused to the 577 C-terminal residues of protein CBFA2T1.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: French-American-British Classification

ValueMeaning.preferredName: French-American-British Classification
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A classification system for acute myeloid leukemias, acute lymphoblastic leukemias, and myelodysplastic syndromes. It is based on the morphologic and cytochemical evaluation of bone marrow and peripheral blood smears.

Concepts.definition: A classification system for acute myeloid leukemias, acute lymphoblastic leukemias, and myelodysplastic syndromes.  It is based on the morphologic and cytochemical evaluation of bone marrow and peripheral blood smears.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Blastic Plasmacytoid Dendritic Cell Neoplasm

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Undifferentiated Leukemia
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A rare acute leukemia of ambiguous lineage in which the blasts do not express markers specific to myeloid or lymphoid lineage.

Concepts.definition: A rare acute leukemia of ambiguous lineage in which the blasts do not express markers specific to myeloid or lymphoid lineage.

PermissibleValues.value: Myeloid leukemia associated with Down syndrome
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Myeloid Leukemia Associated with Down Syndrome

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Myeloid Leukemia Associated with Down Syndrome
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Acute myeloid leukemia or myelodysplastic syndrome occurring in children with Down syndrome.  The acute myeloid leukemia is usually an acute megakaryoblastic leukemia, and is associated with GATA1 gene mutation.

Concepts.longName: Myeloid Leukemia Associated with Down Syndrome
Concepts.definition: Acute myeloid leukemia or myelodysplastic syndrome occurring in children with Down syndrome.  The acute myeloid leukemia is usually an acute megakaryoblastic leukemia, and is associated with GATA1 gene mutation.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Transient Abnormal Myelopoiesis

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Transient Abnormal Myelopoiesis
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A myeloid proliferation occurring in newborns with Down syndrome.  It is clinically and morphologically indistinguishable from acute myeloid leukemia and is associated with GATA1 mutations.  The blasts display morphologic and immunophenotypic features of megakaryocytic lineage.  In the majority of patients the myeloid proliferation undergoes spontaneous remission.

Concepts.longName: Transient Abnormal Myelopoiesis Associated with Down Syndrome
Concepts.definition: A myeloid proliferation occurring in newborns with Down syndrome.  It is clinically and morphologically indistinguishable from acute myeloid leukemia and is associated with GATA1 mutations.  The blasts display morphologic and immunophenotypic features of megakaryocytic lineage.  In the majority of patients the myeloid proliferation undergoes spontaneous remission.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Myeloid Sarcoma

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Myeloid Sarcoma
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A tumor mass composed of myeloblasts or immature myeloid cells.  It occurs in extramedullary sites or the bone.  (WHO, 2001)

Concepts.definition: A tumor mass composed of myeloblasts or immature myeloid cells.  It occurs in extramedullary sites or the bone.  (WHO, 2001)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Pure Erythroid Leukemia

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Pure Erythroid Leukemia
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Acute erythroid leukemia characterised by the presence of immature erythroid cells in the bone marrow (at least 80% of the cellular component), without evidence of a significant myeloblastic cell population present. -- 2003

Concepts.definition: Acute erythroid leukemia characterized by the presence of immature erythroid cells in the bone marrow (at least 80% of the cellular component), without evidence of a significant myeloblastic cell population present.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Therapy-Related Acute Myeloid Leukemia

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Therapy-Related Acute Myeloid Leukemia
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia arising as a result of the mutagenic effect of chemotherapy agents and/or ionizing radiation.  (WHO, 2001)

Concepts.longName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia Post Cytotoxic Therapy
Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia arising as a result of the mutagenic effect of chemotherapy agents and/or ionizing radiation.  (WHO, 2001)

PermissibleValues.value: Acute myeloid leukemia with myelodysplasia-related changes
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with Myelodysplasia-Related Changes

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with Myelodysplasia-Related Changes
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia with at least 20% blasts in the bone marrow or blood, and either a previous history of myelodysplastic syndrome, multilineage dysplasia or myelodysplastic syndrome-related cytogenetic abnormalities.  There is no history of prior cytotoxic therapy for an unrelated disorder, and there is absence of the cytogenetic abnormalities that are present in acute myeloid leukemia with recurrent genetic abnormalities.

Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia with at least 20% blasts in the bone marrow or blood, and either a previous history of myelodysplastic syndrome, multilineage dysplasia or myelodysplastic syndrome-related cytogenetic abnormalities.  There is no history of prior cytotoxic therapy for an unrelated disorder, and there is absence of the molecular abnormalities that are present in acute myeloid leukemia with recurrent genetic abnormalities.

PermissibleValues.value: Provisional entity: AML with mutated CEBPA
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with Mutated CEBPA

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with Mutated CEBPA
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia with mutation of the CEBPA gene. It is usually associated with normal karyotype and most cases meet the criteria for acute myeloid leukemia with or without maturation. Cases with normal karyotype have a favorable prognosis.

Concepts.longName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with CEBPA Mutation
Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia with non-germline mutations of the CEBPA gene.

PermissibleValues.value: Provisional entity: AML with mutated NPM1
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with Mutated NPM1

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with Mutated NPM1
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia with mutation of the nucleophosmin gene. It is usually associated with normal karyotype and frequently has myelomonocytic or monocytic features. It usually responds to induction therapy.

Concepts.longName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with NPM1 Mutation
Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia with mutation of the nucleophosmin gene. It is usually associated with normal karyotype and frequently has myelomonocytic or monocytic features. It usually responds to induction therapy.

PermissibleValues.value: Acute Myeloid Leukemia, other or unclassifiable
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Acute Myeloid Leukemia Not Otherwise Specified

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia Not Otherwise Specified
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Acute myeloid leukemias that do not fulfill the criteria for inclusion in the group of acute myeloid leukemias which have recurrent genetic abnormalities or myelodysplastic changes, or are therapy-related.  This category includes entities classified according to the French-American-British classification scheme.

Concepts.longName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia Not Otherwise Specified
Concepts.definition: Acute myeloid leukemias that do not fulfill the criteria for inclusion in the group of acute myeloid leukemias which have recurrent genetic abnormalities or myelodysplastic changes, or are therapy-related.  This category includes entities classified according to the French-American-British classification scheme.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia with t(15;17)(q22;q12); PML-RARA

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia with t(15;17)(q22;q12); PML-RARA
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia (AML) in which abnormal promyelocytes predominate.  It is characterized by the t(15;17)(q22;q12) translocation.  There are two variants: the typical and microgranular variant.  This AML is particularly sensitive to treatment with all trans-retinoic acid and has a favorable prognosis.  (WHO, 2001)

Concepts.longName: Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia with t(15;17)(q24.1;q21.2); PML-RARA
Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia (AML) in which abnormal promyelocytes predominate. It is characterized by the PML-RARA fusion. There are two variants: the typical and microgranular variant.  This AML is particularly sensitive to treatment with all trans-retinoic acid and has a favorable prognosis. (WHO)

PermissibleValues.value: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with t(8;21)(q22,q22);RUNX1-RUNX1T1 (formerly known as AML1-ETO Fusion Protein Expression)
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with t(8;21)(q22;q22); RUNX1-RUNX1T1

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with t(8;21)(q22;q22); RUNX1-RUNX1T1
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia (AML) showing maturation in the neutrophil lineage.  The bone marrow and the peripheral blood show large myeloblasts with abundant basophilic cytoplasm, often containing azurophilic granules.  This type of AML is associated with good response to chemotherapy and high complete remission rate.  (WHO, 2001)

Concepts.longName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with t(8;21)(q22; q22.1); RUNX1-RUNX1T1
Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia with t(8;21)(q22; q22.1) giving rise to RUNX1/RUNX1T1 fusion transcript and showing maturation in the neutrophil lineage. The bone marrow and the peripheral blood show large myeloblasts with abundant basophilic cytoplasm, often containing azurophilic granules. This type of AML is associated with good response to chemotherapy and high complete remission rate.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Acute Myeloid Leukemia With Recurrent Genetic Abnormalities

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia With Recurrent Genetic Abnormalities
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A clonal expansion of myeloid blasts in the bone marrow, blood or other tissues. The classification of acute myeloid leukemias (AMLs) encompasses four major categories: 1) AML with recurrent genetic abnormalities; 2) AML with multilineage dysplasia; 3) Therapy-related AML; 4) AML not otherwise specified. The required bone marrow or peripheral blood blast percentage for the diagnosis of AML is 20% (WHO classification).: Used to indicate the presence of something or someone.: occurring again.: A molecular or cytogenic abnormality which occurs in either human disease states or disease models.

Concepts.definition: A clonal expansion of myeloid blasts in the bone marrow, blood or other tissues. The classification of acute myeloid leukemias (AMLs) encompasses four major categories: 1) AML with recurrent genetic abnormalities; 2) AML with multilineage dysplasia; 3) Therapy-related AML; 4) AML not otherwise specified. The required bone marrow or peripheral blood blast percentage for the diagnosis of AML is 20% (WHO classification).
Used to indicate the presence of something or someone.
Occurring again.
A molecular or cytogenetic abnormality which occurs in either human disease states or disease models.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: World Health Organization Acute Myeloid Leukemia Category
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A United Nations agency established to coordinate international health activities and to help governments improve health services.:A clonal expansion of myeloid blasts in the bone marrow, blood or other tissues.  The classification of acute myeloid leukemias (AMLs) encompasses four major categories: 1) AML with recurrent genetic abnormalities 2) AML with multilineage dysplasia 3) Therapy-related AML 4) AML not otherwise categorized.  The required bone marrow or peripheral blood blast percentage for the diagnosis of AML has been recently reduced from 30% (French-American-British [FAB] classification) to 20% (WHO classification).  (WHO, 2001) -- 2003:Category; used informally to mean a class of things.

Concepts.definition: A United Nations agency established to coordinate international health activities and to help governments improve health services.

A clonal expansion of myeloid blasts in the bone marrow, blood or other tissues. The classification of acute myeloid leukemias (AMLs) encompasses four major categories: 1) AML with recurrent genetic abnormalities; 2) AML with multilineage dysplasia; 3) Therapy-related AML; 4) AML not otherwise specified. The required bone marrow or peripheral blood blast percentage for the diagnosis of AML is 20% (WHO classification).
A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.
